Declaring a broadcastreceiver for `android.net.conn.CONNECTIVITY_CHANGE` is deprecated for apps targeting N and higher. In general, apps should not rely on this broadcast and instead use `JobScheduler` or `GCMNetworkManager`.

The resource `@style/Base_Theme_AppCompat_Dialog` is marked as private in com.google.android.material:material

This broadcast receiver declares an intent-filter for a protected broadcast action string, which can only be sent by the system, not third-party applications. However, the receiver's onReceive method does not appear to call getAction to ensure that the received Intent's action string matches the expected value, potentially making it possible for another actor to send a spoofed intent with no action string or a different action string and cause undesired behavior.

On SDK version 23 and up, your app data will be automatically backed up and restored on app install. Consider adding the attribute `android:fullBackupContent` to specify an `@xml` resource which configures which files to backup. More info: https://developer.android.com/training/backup/autosyncapi.html
Should explicitly set `android:allowBackup` to `true` or `false` (it's `true` by default, and that can have some security implications for the application's data)
Unnecessary; SDK_INT is always >= 21
Unnecessary; SDK_INT is never < 21
Unnecessary; SDK_INT is always >= 21
